info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued July 01 at 9:34PM MDT until July 01 at 11:30PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... The Hermit`s Peak/Calf Canyon burn scar in... Southwestern Mora County in northeastern New Mexico... Northwestern San Miguel County in northeastern New Mexico... * Until 1130 PM MDT. * At 934 PM MDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain over the Hermit`s Peak/Calf Canyon Burn Scar. Between 0.25 and 0.5 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 0.25 to 0.75 inches in 1 hour. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Excessive rainfall over the burn scar will impact drainages in and around Gascon, Rociada, Mora, and potentially further south in the Gallinas and Tecolote drainage basins. The debris flow can consist of rock, mud, vegetation and other loose materials. HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms in and around the Hermit`s Peak/Calf Canyon Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar and automated gauges. IMPACT...Flooding of areas in and around the Hermit`s Peak/Calf Canyon Burn Scar. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Las Vegas, El Porvenir, Tierra Monte, Gascon, Montezuma, Sapello, Ledoux, Morphy Lake State Park, Upper Colonias, San Ignacio in Guadalupe County, Gallinas, Rociada, Mineral Hill, San Geronimo, Manuelitas, San Pablo, South Carmen, Monte Aplanado and Lower Colonias. This includes the following highways... State Road 94 between Mile Markers 1 and 15. State Road 266 between Mile Markers 0 and 6. State Road 276 between Mile Markers 0 and 5. State Road 518 between Mile Markers 10 and 21. State Road 283 between Mile Markers 2 and 12...and near Mile Marker 14. State Road 65 between Mile Markers 2 and 14. State Road 105 between Mile Markers 0 and 9. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR AND GAUGE INDICATED EXPECTED RAINFALL RATE...0.25-0.75 INCHES IN 1 HOUR
info.instruction: Runoff from rainfall will cause elevated water levels within vulnerable drainages in and downstream of the Hermit`s Peak/Calf Canyon fire burn area. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Do not camp along streams and rivers. Remain alert when hiking in steep, narrow canyons. Know where you are relative to low spots and drainages.
